While META does not handle all possible regular or context-free grammars, it handles a surprisingly large fraction of the grammars encountered by Lisp programmers. We show how META can be used to parse streams, strings and lists---including Common Lisp's hairy lambda expression parameter lists. Finally, we compare the execution time of this parsing method to the built-in methods of Common Lisp.<\/jats:p>","DOI":"10.1145\/121983.121984","type":"journal-article","created":{"date-parts":[[2005,1,26]],"date-time":"2005-01-26T16:09:51Z","timestamp":1106755791000},"page":"3-15","source":"Crossref","is-referenced-by-count":3,"title":"Pragmatic parsing in Common Lisp; or, putting\n defmacro\n on steroids","prefix":"10.1145","volume":"IV","author":[{"given":"Henry G.","family":"Baker","sequence":"first","affiliation":[]}],"member":"320","reference":[{"key":"e_1_2_1_1_1","volume-title":"Techniques and Tools.
